column2: As a new feudal lord, your first priority is to secure an heir. If you do not have a legitimate heir when your character dies, it's Game Over. Other pressing matters that need your attention will appear as Alerts along the top of the screen.

You can issue commands both while the game is paused and when the clock is running. To pause or unpause the game, click the date in the upper-right corner or press the Spacebar. Use the plus and minus symbols to speed time up or to slow it down.
Unless your dynasty dies out or you lose your last piece of land, the game will end in the year 962 AD, and you can compare your success with that of other dynasties from real history.

In 'The Winter King', you play as a feudal ruler of western Europe during the Dark Ages. Your goal is to secure as much land and prestige as possible for yourself and, when the time comes, your successors. You can see your portrait in the upper-left corner. Click the portrait to find out who your character is.

The campaign takes place on a fully 3D map. You can zoom in and out using your mouse scroll wheel. Holding down the scroll wheel and moving the mouse lets you pan. You can always reset the map by pressing Backspace.

column2: The oldest child of the ruler inherits all titles. Your successor will like the law, but other members of your dynasty will slightly disapprove.
The oldest member of the dynasty inherits all titles. Your oldest child will greatly disapprove of this law, but all other members of the dynasty will approve.

The ruler and each lower rank vassal can nominate a successor from among themselves and legitimate children and siblings of the ruler. Elective succession is popular with the vassals, but they will not approve if their liege personally holds too many elector titles.
The titles of the ruler are divided among his children, with the oldest getting the primary title. Gavelkind is a very popular law with everyone except the oldest child.

The most powerful son of the ruler succeeds, though other powerful sons are likely to intervene... The law is very popular with your children, except for the oldest child. The rest of your dynasty also approves.
All vassals and courtiers get a vote and decide on a successor from among themselves.
If the liege lord has nominated a successor, he succeeds. Otherwise, the Papal Candidate is chosen.
Women can inherit, but only if there are no eligible males.
Women inherit on the same grounds men do.
Tales of your misdeeds are told from Britain to Constantinople.
May you be sewn up alive in the belly of a dead ox.
May your humors rot in your living body.
May your years be short and miserable.
§Y$NAME$§! is currently traveling in distant lands, or missing, or in an unknown location.
was offered up in sacrifice to the Gods by $KILLER$
was offered up in sacrifice to the Gods
in unknown circumstances or possibly went missing
This province suffers from the devastating epidemic known as the Plague of Justinian.
This character suffers from the dreaded bubonic plague known as the Plague of Justinian.
The foreign people who have arrived on these isles have bought with them new diseases, which collectively are killing off the local Britons.
This character has the Saxon plague, a collection of diseases introduced to the British Isles by the invading Germans.
There is an epidemic of the Roman Fever, also known as malaria, in this province.
This character has contracted the Roman Fever, also known as malaria.
The majority of the populace in the province of §Y$NAME$§! has changed culture and is now §Y$CULTURENAME$§!.
The majority of the populace in the province of §Y$NAME$§! has converted to the §Y$RELIGIONNAME$§! religion.
Levy at disposal due to laws and ruler's martial skills: §Y$VALUE$%§!
Yearly Tax Paid to Us / Total Yearly Income
Levy Raisable by Us / Total Max Levy
Feudal Levy Laws control the proportion of their levies that vassal lords nominally have to provide their liege.
Vassal lords must only provide you with a small part of their levies.
Vassal lords may retain a significant portion of their levies for themselves.
Vassal lords retain small local retinues in addition to their garrisons.
Vassal lords are obliged to provide their entire levy to their liege.
Normally, feudal lords are exempt from paying taxes to their liege. However, other arrangements are fairly common - if not well liked.
Feudal lords are exempted from taxation, vassal lords like this state of affairs.
Feudal lords are expected to make a small financial contribution towards the greater good of the realm. They are mildly disappointed in this.
Feudal lords are expected to make a moderate financial contribution towards the greater good of the realm. They also wish to express their general disappointment at this state of affairs.
Feudal lords are expected to make a large financial contribution towards the greater good of the realm. They find it hard to fully express their disgust at this state of affairs.
Town Levy Laws concern the obligations of towns and cities to provide troops for their liege.
The towns are expected to provide a small amount of troops for the defense of the realm.
The towns are expected to provide a moderate amount of troops for the defense of the realm.
The towns are expected to provide a substantial amount of troops for the defense of the realm.
The towns are expected to provide the largest possible portion of their available troops for the defense of the realm.
The towns and their markets are the golden geese of any realm, but their taxation can be adjusted through laws.
The towns are expected to make a small financial contribution to the greater good of the realm.
The towns are expected to make a moderate financial contribution to the greater good of the realm.
The towns are expected to make a substantial financial contribution to the greater good of the realm.
The towns are expected to make a large financial contribution to the greater good of the realm.
These laws control the size of the levies that vassal druids, pagan priests and bishops are formally obliged to provide their secular liege.
The priests are expected to provide a small amount of troops for the defense of the realm.
The priests are expected to provide a moderate amount of troops for the defense of the realm.
The priests are expected to provide a substantial amount of troops for the defense of the realm.
The priests are expected to provide a large amount of troops for the defense of the realm.
Priests and bishops nominally provide their secular liege with a regular tithe, unless they like the head of their religion better.
Priests are expected to make a small financial contribution to the greater good of the realm.
Priests are expected to make a moderate financial contribution to the greater good of the realm.
Priests are expected to make a substantial financial contribution to the greater good of the realm.

These laws regulate the amount of combat training and discipline required from men who enlist or are pressed into the realm's levies. With more training, your warriors will be more confident and effective on the field of battle, but more time will be necessary to replace the losses.

Your levies consist of free individuals, local farmers and commoners who are given arms and called to war when necessary. They receive no direct training, and no strict discipline is required from them.
When men enlist or are pressed into your levies, they recieve basic drill instruction and weapons training at the hands of veterans.

Your levies consist of competent, well-trained professionals, drilled and honed by veterans and skilled commanders. Strict discipline is required from all armed men, even from town guards and watch sentries. Peasant militia levies spend one day every week training under the guidance of experienced warriors.
This law determines who appoints landed priests and bishops - the secular liege or the religious authorities.
Only the Pope may appoint Bishops within the Realm. This will give the Crown a §G50%§! Piety cost discount when requesting special papal actions, like Divorce and Excommunication.
Landed priests within the kingdom can be appointed by their secular lieges, and will be more loyal to their liege than to the head of their religion.
Towns and cities within the Kingdom can only be vassals of the King.
Ancient kings and emperors fought a constant battle with their vassals over privileges, rights and obligations. The lords, naturally, tended to favor a weak central power...
Vassals are a law unto themselves, ruling their fiefs like petty kingdoms. Their obligations to their liege are minimal.
Vassals enjoy a very large degree of autonomy, but have to provide their liege with a fairly substantial portion of the levies.
The powers of the nobility and the monarch are in precarious balance. Vassals can no longer wage private wars within the realm.
The monarch has curbed the rights of the high nobility, relying instead on a budding bureaucracy led by the lesser nobility.
The lords of the realm are chafing under the unrestricted powers of an absolute monarch.
These laws govern the ability of vassals to fight their own individual wars against each other and outside realms.
Vassals are allowed to wage war against other vassals in the realm, as well as against foreign realms.
Vassals are not allowed to wage war against other vassals, but can declare war on foreign realms.
Vassals are completely restricted from declaring war.

While not a fully fledged imperial, bureaucratic system, Romanized realms retain the concept of the realm as a proper state rather than the more personal feudal system. Romanized realms are more centralized and tend to have greater control over their vassals, as well as a system of inheritance that transfers the state or administration in full.
The Council's authority in regards to the right of holding office.
The ruler has full authority over the choice of who sits on the council.
The Council's authority reaches its peak, with the ruler unable to fire council members at will.
§YPowerful Vassals§! cannot be fired from the §YCouncil§!
§YPowerful Vassals§! can be fired from the §YCouncil§!
With low organization chiefs have barely any control over their vassals.
Chiefs have limited power over their vassals, but still have little hard power.
Chiefs have begun to gain some authority over their vassals.
The power of vassals and liege chiefs are somewhat balanced.
Chiefs are gaining in power over their vassals.
Vassals owe significant obligations to their chiefs.
The power of individual tribes has been largely subsumed, and chiefs rule over their vassals much like feudal lords.
The Crown Laws of the §Y$CROWN_TITLE$§!\napply in the §Y$TITLE$§!
You need to hold at least §Y$DUCHIES$§! High Lordship titles.

We need to control §Y$REQ_PERC$%§! of its de jure provinces to create this title. Currently, we control $PERC$ ($HELD$/§Y$ALL$§!). Creating this title would give you §G$PRESTIGE$§! Prestige and cost you §R$GOLD$§! Gold and §R$PIETY$§! Piety.

We need to control §Y$REQ_PERC$%§! of its de jure provinces to create this title. Currently, we control $PERC$ ($HELD$/§Y$ALL$§!). Creating this title would give you §G$PRESTIGE$§! Prestige and cost you §R$GOLD$§! Gold and §R$PIETY$§! Piety.

We need to control §Y$REQ_PERC$%§! of its de jure provinces to create this title. Currently, we control $PERC$ ($HELD$/§Y$ALL$§!). Creating this title would give you §G$PRESTIGE$§! Prestige and cost you §R$GOLD$§! Gold.

We need to control §Y$REQ_PERC$%§! of its de jure provinces to usurp this title. Currently, we control $PERC$ ($HELD$/§Y$ALL$§!). Usurping this title would give you §G$PRESTIGE$§! Prestige and cost you §R$GOLD$§! Gold.
